page.title: 02Derivation of place-names
page.content: The village of Lyford was previously Lingford, meaning "the ford by which flax grew". No such crop is grown today but wild flax maybe found on wet areas fringing the river. The River Ock derives its name from the pre-Saxon word "Ock" meaning a young salmon. Due to heavy pollution of the Thames salmon has not been seen since the turn of the century. The meaning of "Charney Bassett" is "Cearn-isle" or the island beside the river Cearn or Charn, a Celtic name forthe River Ock. Bassett comes from the Norman family of Ralph Bassett who held land in the district. The names of 2 fields near Charney Bassett, are "Clover Ground" and "Nightlie", which probably originate from the days of common grazing.
